channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021 The New York Times Company

item.title: Prince Philip, Husband of Queen Elizabeth II, Is Dead at 99
item.description: The Duke of Edinburgh, who married the future queen in 1947, brought the monarchy into the 20th century, but his occasional tactless comments hurt his image.
item.dc:creator: Marilyn Berger
item.media:description: Philip in 1966. He was often seen in public dressed in full military regalia, an emblem of his high-ranking titles in the armed forces.

item.title: Volcano Erupts on Island of St. Vincent and the Grenadines
item.description: La Soufrière, on the main island of St. Vincent and the Grenadines, last erupted in 1979. It sent two explosive plumes of ash and smoke on Friday, and 20,000 people fled.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Cooke and Oscar Lopez
item.media:description: Smoke and ash billow from La Soufriere on St. Vincent on Friday.

item.title: India Covid-19 Crisis Deepened by Missteps and Complacency
item.description: The new wave will hurt global efforts and vaccine supplies, experts say. Researchers are scrambling to assess whether new coronavirus variants are playing a role in India.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
item.media:description: Amit Shah at an election rally on Saturday.

item.title: Vaccine Passports Could Unlock World Travel and Cries of Discrimination
item.description: Vaccine rollouts in some countries have a long-locked-down world dreaming of travels abroad again. But they have also set off a fraught debate about the fairness of a two-tier system for haves and have-nots.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Dan Balilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israelis showing their “Green Pass” before entering a concert in Tel Aviv last month.

item.title: For Prince Philip, Royal Family Plans Pandemic-Muted Honors
item.description: Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh, will not lie in state for public viewing and the funeral will not be open to the public, in a nod to a ban on mass gatherings and the prince’s own wishes.
item.dc:creator: Richard Pérez-Peña and Marc Santora
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A crowd gathered outside Buckingham Palace in London on Friday.

item.title: Russian Troop Movements and Talk of Intervention Cause Jitters in Ukraine
item.description: Russia has amassed more troops on the Ukrainian border than at any time since 2014. Western governments are asking: Why now?
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in a trench on the front lines facing Russian-backed separatists near the town of Zolote this month.

item.title: Vaccine Passports: What Are They, and Who Might Need One?
item.description: The concept of documenting vaccinations is being taken to new levels of sophistication, and experts predict that electronic verification will soon become commonplace.
item.dc:creator: Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:credit: Dan Balilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli woman showing her Green Pass before entering a show at an opera house in Tel Aviv.

item.title: In Haifa, Israel, Wild Boars Encroach on Human Turf
item.description: Groups of boars have become an unavoidable presence in Haifa. Some human residents are charmed, but others are annoyed or frightened and now carry sticks on walks.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Dan Balilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: A boar crossing in Haifa, which stopped shooting the animals in 2019.

item.title: Chinese Reality Shows Censor Western Clothing Brands
item.description: Online platforms that stream dance, singing and comedy shows are pixelating performers’ T-shirts and sneakers amid a nationalistic fervor.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May

item.title: For a U.K. Satirist and His Online Fans, Comedy Is Catharsis
item.description: Lockdown has helped establish Munya Chawawa as a sardonic voice for young people who don’t often recognize themselves in the comedians they see on TV.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Munya Chawawa, whose sendups of race and class issues have won him an online following, at his home in South London.

item.title: Are Your Illegal Drugs Pure? New Zealand Will Check Them for You.
item.description: A law will allow controlled substances to be tested without penalty to ensure their authenticity. The goals are to reduce health risks and, perhaps, change users’ behavior.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: New Zealand has enacted the Drug Checking Act after a one-year pilot program found that contaminants were common in illegal drugs.

item.title: Northern Ireland Sees Spasm of Violence as Old Tensions Resurface
item.description: Brexit and Covid have brought longtime grievances to the surface and protests to the streets.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: A bus was hijacked and set on fire on Wednesday in Belfast, Northern Ireland.

item.title: Royal Rivalry Bares Social Tensions Behind Jordan’s Stable Veneer
item.description: The standoff between King Abdullah II and his half brother, Prince Hamzah, wasn’t just palace intrigue. It hinted at Saudi meddling and highlighted wider tensions within Jordan’s complex society.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Rana F. Sweis and Eric Schmitt
item.category: Hamzah bin Hussein, Prince of Jordan
item.media:description: A poster of King Abdullah II of Jordan on a street in Amman on Wednesday.

item.title: Turkey Fights for Return of a Work It Says Was Looted
item.description: A bench trial in Federal District Court in Manhattan concerns an ancient idol held by Christie’s.
item.dc:creator: Colin Moynihan
item.media:description: An image of what is known as “The Guennol Stargazer,” from a legal document in the lawsuit against Christie’s.

item.title: A Bleak Forecast for Canada’s 600,000 Energy Industry Workers
item.description: A report forecasts that up to three quarters of their jobs may vanish in a low carbon future and suggests a better approach to retraining.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Alec Jacobson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A crew closing a well in Alliance, Alberta.

item.title: Pfizer Requests Authorization to Use Vaccine in Young Teens
item.description: If the emergency use authorization is broadened, young adolescents could start getting vaccinated before going back to school in the fall.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:description: A teenager receives a dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine in New York on Tuesday. The companies asked to expand their vaccine’s emergency use authorization to include adolescents ages 12 to 15.

item.title: Blood Clots Linked to AZ Vaccine Stem From Rare Antibody Reaction
item.description: New studies from Germany and Norway examined cases involving mostly younger people who developed serious and sometimes fatal blood disorders.
item.dc:creator: Denise Grady
item.media:description: A dose of the AstraZeneca vaccine being administered in Bucharest, Romania, in February. The vaccine has been a mainstay of inoculation programs in more than 100 countries.

item.title: Netflix's ‘The Crown’ Changed Prince Philip’s Image
item.description: The Netflix show exposed a new generation to the prince’s life and helped reshape those already familiar with his legacy.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall

item.title: Michigan’s governor, confronting a surge in virus cases, calls on Biden for more vaccines.
item.description: Gov. Gretchen Whitmer, a Democrat, said she had pushed the president unsuccessfully to send more vaccines to her state, where hospitals are filling.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith and Julie Bosman
item.media:credit: Jake May/The Flint Journal, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A person received a dose of the coronavirus vaccine last month at Bishop Airport in Flint, Mich.

item.title: Prince Philip’s Life in Pictures
item.description: Philip’s life spanned almost a century of upheaval for Britain: He had lived with a granddaughter of Queen Victoria, and he died nearly 100 years old in an era of smartphones and the internet.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Iran Nuclear Talks Start on Positive Note in Vienna
item.description: Working groups on sanctions and uranium enrichment are making progress, diplomats said. The indirect negotiations between Tehran and Washington are set to resume next week.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: The Grand Hotel in Vienna this week, where diplomats from the European Union, China, Russia and Iran held talks on the Iran nuclear deal.

item.title: To Speed Vaccination, Some Call for Delaying Second Shots
item.description: Stretching the time between the first and second doses would greatly accelerate the rate at which people get at least partial protection. But some experts fear it could also lead to new variants.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:description: A mass Pfizer-BioNTech vaccination clinic set up at the Derby Arena in England last month.

item.title: Prince Philip, Style Icon
item.description: How do you convey royalty without overshadowing the most royal?
item.dc:creator: Guy Trebay
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Prince Philip holds a beer while umpiring a polo match at Ham Common, Richmond.

item.title: Prince Philip will lie in rest at Windsor Castle before a funeral in St. George’s Chapel.
item.description: On the day he died, the death toll from Covid-19 in Britain was over 150,000. Officials said the public would be discouraged from participating in funeral services.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:description: An electronic billboard in Piccadilly Circus in London displayed a tribute to Prince Philip on Friday.

item.title: Boris Johnson Reacts to Prince Philip's Death
item.description: The prime minister was among several leaders around Britain to offer condolences after the death of Prince Philip.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson in London.

item.title: Prince Philip died at 99 at his home in Windsor Castle.
item.dc:creator: Marilyn Berger
item.media:description: Prince Philip in St. George’s Chapel in Windsor Castle near London in 2018.

item.title: German lawmakers move to strengthen the government’s powers in the pandemic.
item.description: A plan to bolster Germany’s pandemic law will make it easier for the government to enforce restrictions to stop the spread of the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Lena Mucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Berlin last month.

item.title: The New Taiwan Tensions
item.description: China is getting more aggressive. Would the U.S. go to war to protect the island?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Figures of nationalist soldiers are part of a display on Lieyu Island. The Chinese city of Xiamen lies across the water.

item.title: The U.S.S. Johnston Sank in 1944. A Crew Just Visited Its Wreckage.
item.description: The shipwreck, 21,000 feet underwater, was discovered in 2019. A team of explorers has now confirmed that it was the Navy destroyer that played a key role in helping General MacArthur retake the Philippines.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A shipwreck near the Philippines was confirmed last month as the U.S.S. Johnston, which Japanese forces sank in 1944.

item.title: Hong Kong residents stranded in Britain meet frustration as they try to return.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:description: A man waiting for the results of a mandatory Covid-19 test given to all new arrivals at Hong Kong International Airport in October.

item.title: The struggle against vaccine hesitancy comes to Mississippi.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs
item.media:credit: Rory Doyle for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers assisting people who received the Moderna vaccine at a drive-through site on the campus of Delta State University in Cleveland, Miss., in March.

item.title: As a virus variant sweeps Europe, a look at lessons for the rest of the world.
item.dc:creator: Josh Holder, Allison McCann and Benjamin Mueller

item.title: Iran Releases South Korean Oil Tanker
item.description: The vessel was seized in January. Iran said the ship had been polluting its waters, but the move was seen as an effort to force South Korea to unlock billions in funds caught up in U.S. sanctions.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:credit: South Korea Foreing Ministry, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photograph released by the South Korean Foreign Ministry showed the MT Hankuk Chemi leaving the Iranian port city of Bandar Abbas on Friday.

item.title: Does an ‘Asian-Australian’ Accent Exist?
item.description: Is there something a little bit different about the way Asian-Australian native English speakers, like myself, talk?
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: David Maurice Smith for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sydney suburb of Chatswood in 2018.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: The dangerous rise of coronavirus variants.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times

item.title: Macron Closes ENA, in Bid to Diversify France's Public Service
item.description: The institution had become a symbol of privilege in a society where social mobility has broken down.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron attended the Ecole Nationale d’Administration, as did predecessors François Hollande and Jacques Chirac.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: More countries halt AstraZeneca vaccine use.
item.dc:creator: Whet Moser
item.media:description: Administering the AstraZeneca vaccine at a sports arena in San Juan, Philippines, last month.

item.title: Afghan War Casualty Report: April 2021
item.description: At least 72 pro-government forces and 18 civilians were killed in Afghanistan so far this month.
item.dc:creator: Fahim Abed
item.media:description: People gather at the scene of an explosion that targeted a police vehicle in Jalalabad in eastern Afghanistan on April 7.

item.title: With U.S. Asylum System Closed to Many, Some Find Sanctuary in Mexico
item.description: A record number of people petitioned for asylum in Mexico last month, drawn by family ties and high approval rates — and discouraged by the difficulty of getting into the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Kirk Semple
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants crossing the Rio Bravo at Ciudad Juarez, Mexico in March, trying to request asylum from U.S. Border Patrol agents.

item.title: In New Holocaust Survivor Testimony, Hate Speech Is a Dangerous Seed
item.description: A new campaign called #ItStartedWithWords features short videos from Holocaust survivors on the origins of World War II and offers a timely message amid an outbreak of anti-Asian hate.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany
item.media:description: Sidney Zoltak, center right, standing at his father’s grave in Milan in the mid-1940s with his mother, Henia, and two friends.

item.title: Archaeologists in Egypt Find Ancient City More Than 3,000 Years Old
item.description: The newly discovered city was built more than 3,400 years ago during the opulent reign of Amenhotep III, one of Egypt’s most powerful pharaohs.
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.media:credit: Zahi Hawass Center for Egyptology, via Reuters
item.media:description: A new archaeological discovery near Luxor in an undated photo from the the Zahi Hawass Center for Egyptology.

item.title: Slovakia Claims a Bait-and-Switch With the Russian Vaccines it Ordered
item.description: Slovakia says that Sputnik V doses it received did “not have the same characteristics and properties” as a version endorsed by a respected British medical journal.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: The former Slovak prime minister, Igor Matovic, at the airport in Kosice, Slovakia, in March, to welcome the arrival of the Russian-developed Sputnik V vaccine.

item.title: Has the Era of Overzealous Cleaning Finally Come to an End?
item.description: This week, the C.D.C. acknowledged what scientists have been saying for months: The risk of catching the coronavirus from surfaces is low.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Celeste Noche for The New York Times
item.media:description: A hotel room in Long Beach, Wash., being fogged with sanitizer. “There’s really no evidence that anyone has ever gotten Covid-19 by touching a contaminated surface,” one researcher noted.

item.title: Sharon Matola, Who Opened a Zoo in the Jungle of Belize, Dies at 66
item.description: An Air Force veteran and former lion tamer, she helped her adopted country fall in love with tapirs, macaws and peccaries.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.category: Belize Zoo and Tropical Education Center (Belize)
item.media:description: Sharon Matola in 2001 at her zoo. She became a fixture in Belizean society, and spoke out against development projects she deemed to be a threat to her adopted country’s natural endowment.

item.title: Puerto Rico Adults to Be Eligible for Covid Vaccine on Monday
item.description: Puerto Rico also announced a longer overnight curfew until May 9 as cases rise on the island.
item.dc:creator: Andrés R. Martínez
item.media:credit: Erika P. Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Waiting under observation after receiving a Covid-19 vaccine last month in Vieques in Puerto Rico.

item.title: Kati Kariko Helped Shield the World From the Coronavirus
item.description: Collaborating with devoted colleagues, Dr. Kariko laid the groundwork for the mRNA vaccines turning the tide of the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata
item.media:description: Katalin Kariko at her home in Jenkintown, Pa., in February. Dr. Kariko’s early research into mRNA eventually led to development of the Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech vaccines.

item.title: U.S. Intelligence Report Warns of Global Consequences of Social Fragmentation
item.description: The coronavirus pandemic has highlighted weaknesses of the international order, said the report, which is issued every four years.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: The coronavirus pandemic has shown that the existing world order may be ill-equipped to confront crises, a new intelligence report said.

item.title: Outcry in Pakistan After Imran Khan Links Rape to How Women Dress
item.description: Activists have accused Prime Minister Imran Khan of “baffling ignorance” and victim-blaming after he said rape cases had risen because of “vulgarity.”
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood
item.media:description: Prime Minister Imra Khan of Pakistan, last year.

item.title: N.Y.C.’s Mayor Says New Virus Rule Will Reduce Temporary Public School Closures
item.description: Public schools had previously closed for 10 days if two unlinked cases were detected there, regardless of the source of infection.
item.dc:creator: Eliza Shapiro
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students outside I.S. 238 last month.

item.title: Corporate Taxes Are Wealth Taxes
item.description: And their decline has led to a steep drop in tax rates for the affluent.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Eduardo Munoz Alvarez/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Frederick Smith, FedEx CEO, on his way to visit President-elect Donald Trump in 2016. FedEx paid no corporate taxes last year.

item.title: South Korean Man Gets 34 Years for Running Sexual Exploitation Chat Room
item.description: Moon Hyeong-wook, 25, was accused of luring young women with promises of high-paying jobs and then forcing them into pornography.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: An office of the Korea Communications Standards Commission, which is responsible for finding and removing sex videos posted online without consent.

item.title: Biden Backs Taiwan, but Some Call for a Clearer Warning to China
item.description: As China grows stronger and bolder, some experts want to end Washington’s decades-long policy of “strategic ambiguity.”
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Pictures of President Tsai Ing-wen of Taiwan and China’s leader, Xi Jinping, last year in Taipei. American officials warn that China is growing more capable of invading the democratic island.

item.title: For 10 Years, Photographer Follows Up on Destroyed Village
item.description: After an earthquake and a tsunami hit Japan in 2011, Hiroko Masuike, a Times photographer, spent a decade documenting the attempts by 15 people to rebuild their community.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Sedacca
item.media:description: Relatives of Shuji Morioka, a tsunami victim, at a memorial park in Rikuzentakata on the 10th anniversary of the disaster last month.

item.title: ‘No More Parties’: Mexico’s Piñata Makers Badly Bruised by Pandemic
item.description: The piñata industry, dependent on social gatherings, has seen sales plummet. Some artisans, in a creative bid to survive, have added coronavirus figures to their lineups of superheros and princesses.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Lopez
item.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times
item.media:description: A piñata shop in Mexico City. The industry has struggled across Mexico this year.

item.title: Amid Sexual Harassment Scandals, Australia Plots a ‘Road Map for Respect’
item.description: Prime Minister Scott Morrison said he would accept 55 suggestions from the country’s human rights commissioner to tackle a problem that has been festering for years in politics.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: Prime Minister Scott Morrison of Australia said his government accepted 55 recommendations that aim to prevent gender-based abuse and increase accountability for misbehavior in the workplace.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: France’s delayed #MeToo.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Abdulmonam Eassa/Barcroft Media, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Protesting the nomination of Gérald Darmanin as interior minister in Paris in July. Mr. Darmanin is under investigation in a rape case that was reopened last year.

item.title: In France’s Delayed #MeToo, Powerful Men Fall, One After Another
item.description: Since the start of the year, well-known men from diverse fields have been accused of sexual abuse and placed under investigation.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Abdulmonam Eassa/Barcroft Media, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Protesting the nomination of Gérald Darmanin as interior minister in July. Mr. Darmanin is under investigation in a rape case that was reopened last year.
